verses.text: Blessed are all who fear the LORD, who walk in his ways.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 128:1
rsbNotes.text:
128:1 fears the Lord. See notes Ps. 34:7; 36:1; 119:63.

walks in his ways. Those who obey God’s will for their lives as manifested in His law.

verses.text: You will eat the fruit of your labor; blessings and prosperity will be yours.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 128:2
rsbNotes.text: 128:2 the labor of your hands. One result of the Fall was that Adam would have to work hard to get food on the table (Gen. 3:17–19). The Preacher of Ecclesiastes was driven to despair because some people labored while others, less deserving, enjoyed the benefits of their labor (Eccl. 5:8–6:12; Is. 65:22). The psalmist envisions the righteous prospering from their own labor, a just situation.

verses.text: Your wife will be like a fruitful vine within your house; your sons will be like olive shoots around your table.
Thus is the man blessed who fears the LORD.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 128:3
rsbNotes.text:
128:3 a fruitful vine. The vine produced the grapes for wine, a source of joy to the Israelites (Ps. 104:15). The blessing that the fruitful wife brings includes children around the table.

olive shoots. Olives and olive oil were valued staple commodities in the nation’s life.

verses.text: May the LORD bless you from Zion all the days of your life; may you see the prosperity of Jerusalem,

rsbNotes.title: Ps 128:5
rsbNotes.text: 128:5 from Zion. That is, from the temple (Ps. 2:6; 50:2).

verses.text: and may you live to see your children's children. Peace be upon Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 128:6
rsbNotes.text:
128:6 your children’s children. Long life and large families were a blessing in ancient Israel, particularly in the light of the Abrahamic covenant (Gen. 12:1–3).

Peace. See 122:6 note.
